												I was 3D Worms fan as a kid. Is this game is a childhood ruined or exchanced? I'm on the fence.This game is more or less an expanded version of old Worms 4: Mayhem. However, overall experience isn't what fun, thanks to the sluggish weapon and utilities physics. Weapons behave very strangely. Some are extremely reliable (constant 50DMG Bazooka shots) or suprisingly unreliable (Banana Bomb). On top of that, AI is still stupid as a Sheep. Team 17 never programmed a fine artificial enemies.Worms 4 singleplayer missions are uninspired. they are paired with pretty bland story around them. The included Worms 3D missions are more interesting. They are compact, focused and not bounded in half-baked story arcs.Menus ergonomy and UI needs a complete rework. Hidden important options, difficult navigation, poor visuals.This game is somethat a fun experience, but you need other people with the same preference to the 3D Worms games as you. With friends, you will have a blast, thanks to the better controls and hilarity of events. You don't have such people around you? Make a pass. You had enough of Worms in 3D (no matter, if in the good or bad way)? Make a pass. I'm still giving this game a Upvote, but it is a close one. 												The two 3D Worms titles (Worms 3D and Worms 4: Mayhem) packaged together in a collector's edition of sorts, which comes with many small improvements (mostly graphical). The 3D entries are typically held to be the weakest in the series, but I think they have been unjustly treated by most players. The game as a whole seems to lack the elegance (it does take quite a bit longer to learn the basics) of the 2D titles, and there's not much that can be done about that - It has less of that "pick up and play" quality of the other Worms games.If you do get over the initial bump, you'll discover a rather charming turn based artillery game. All of the classic tactical considerations return in 3D (try having your bazooka shot be influenced by 3D wind!), and many new ones are introduced. Most of the old weapon and equipment dynamics remain, though to different degrees of fidelity and with an eye on enabling the new gameplay. Even terrain destruction is back, though the granularity of their weird "poxel" technology can often appear low (i.e. terrain and objects are composed of only a few large "chunks"), and the environmental damage always occurs in a distinctly "blocky" fashion.It feels like a console port through and through (you cannot even select weapons with hotkeys - a staple of PC Worms), and the UI is rather garish. The game can be a bit unstable, and crashes when you minimize/maximize the game window are not unheard of.Even if it didn't have a solid and enjoyable MP mode (if lacking in customization options), I would still recommend this game solely for its campaign. Worms 3D and Worms 4: Mayhem have by far the best SP missions of any Worms game, and they're all available in Ultimate Mayhem. A lot of variety and creativity on display, and it can be rather challenging to beat the par time on some of them. It really does seem like the SP was Team 17's main focus for the 3D games, which makes them even more unusual.

												Worms has always held a very strong position in my opinion. It wears it's heart on it's sleeve: It isn't an A-List game and it isn't for everyone. But for me, it's one of the most passionately developed game series ever.Things have certainly moved on since the side-scrolling invertibrate slaughter-fest of the first games to the 3D variants of the game. And whilst I did love the 2D games, I have to admit that I prefer the 3D versions. Ultimate mayhem combines the best bits of two great titles: Worms 3D and Worms 3: Mayhem, keeping all the best bits from both and removing the bad. The customisation is absolutely fantastic: Worms with Pope hats and 3D glasses shooting bazookas at Worms with Bunny ears and disco glasses has to be one of the most hilarious things in gaming.As I said before, it's turn-based nature and sometimes fairly difficult missions are not for everyone. But if the thought of carnage, explosions, flying sheep bombs, alien abductions, an endless array of hats and voices, air-strikes and a huge concrete donkey even makes you smile, then perhaps you should give this game a look.You won't regret it.

												A bit of a underrated gem, Worms Ultimate Mayhem came in and out of the spotlight rather quietly. It merged together "Worms 3D" and "Worms 4 Mayhem", two games previously released in 2004 and 2005 (Respectively). Using comedic weapons that'd you expect to see in a cartoon, you battle your way to defeat all the opposing worms. It's mindless, but at the same time fun. The game can be fairly difficult in some of the challenges, but it feels just right.My only real complaint with the game is the lack of being able to easily create / import other maps. All this game needs is a level editor and perhaps a few more character creation options and it would be amazing. None the less, a truly great game.

Posted: January 5, 2015
												Unlike most of the previous 2D Worms games, Worms Ultimate Mayhem features a 3D, turn-based artillery strategy that allows player to move freely rather from left and right. In the game lobby, players are able to choose from a wide variety of different weapons and use them when the game starts. At the start of the game each player is able to control four worms, due to the game turned-base nature, each player control one worm at a time with a set time limit; when the time limit expires or when the worm fires a weapon, the player's turn will end and the opponent will start his turn. The objective of the game is to eliminate all of the enemy team worms. There are two ways that a worm can be eliminated. The simplest way is to deplete the worm of its health, that can be done by choosing a weapon, aiming it at the enemy worm, and firing at the opposing team worm. The second way is to knock the worm out of the platform; some weapons provide the ability to push or knock back the opposing worm. Once a worm is eliminated, it cannot be brought back to life and once all four of a player's worms are eliminated the game will end. The team with worms left standing is the winner.

												This is taken from a comment I wrote on YouTube a while ago, I'm posting it here as my review. Edited it a little, also.I have the game on the PlayStation 3 too (don't ask why I have it for both the PC and PlayStation 3). To be honest, I prefer Worms 4: Mayhem (I only have it for the PC, pirated copy from 2005/2006). It has better game-play (it's better for battling, Roping, navigating, etc. and don't ask why, hard to explain it), better tweaks (Is it even possible to tweak Worms: Ultimate Mayhem? I have the PC version of the game and I don't know how to tweak it. There are no ".xml" files.), better music (this is my opinion, the Worms: Ultimate Mayhem music is great too, they're remixes of the old Worms 4: Mayhem tracks, but it really sucks that they took out the old Worms 4: Mayhem Sudden Death theme, they could have made a remix of that), better online play (They removed the Wormpot for online games in Worms: Ultimate Mayhem! How could they do this to us?! And you can't actually pick your own team in Worms: Ultimate Mayhem for online play, it picks one of your teams automatically, and it doesn't display the name of the team at the beginning of your turn, it simply shows your player name instead.), better HUD... They even removed the Icarus Potion Cheat in Worms: Ultimate Mayhem! I have 12 Worms games, including Worms Armageddon (the so-called "best game in the series", yes, it may be the best 2D game), and Worms 4: Mayhem was always my favorite, and Worms: Ultimate Mayhem is a very close second (and Worms 3D is third, but not that close). Yes, the new HD graphics for Worms: Ultimate Mayhem are nice, so are the new sound effects and the new "Credits" screen (it has humorous cut-scenes), and I like the Binoculars (although I was hoping for all Worms 3D weapons mixed with the Worms 4: Mayhem weapons), the new online features are also nice (such as "Ranked Match", but I still prefer the Worms 4: Mayhem online system), and they also added all the Worms 3D maps as well, along with the Worms 3D Campaign, which is very important. But, to be honest, I don't think they'll ever make a game that could top good old Worms 4: Mayhem.As for Worms: Ultimate Mayhem, the PC and PlayStation 3 versions are equally as good. For the PC version, you could change the controls for your keyboard and controller too, which is very important. In the PlayStation 3 version, you can't change the controls for your controller, you can only choose three default sets for all controls on the controller ("Goofy", "Classic", and "Mayhem"). But for the PlayStation 3 version, there's a larger limit to the amount of characters for weapon and Game Style names, which is also very important. It also has a sufficient amount of characters for team names. For the PC version, it only has a large enough character limit for team names, not weapon or Game Style names. So, as I said, they're both equally as good.﻿But in general, I'd highly recommend this game. It's one of the best I've ever played.

												I have only played this for a couple of hours but I know enough to get a solid impression. As someone who has played Worms 3D on the Playstation 2 and enjoyed it as a kid... I have to say this is disappointing.Firstly, the things that I enjoyed doing as a kid are all there. That being, the ability to make a few teams, and then a game mode where all the weapons are unlocked with no restrictions. Yes you are able to do this, but it may at first look like there is no way to impliment this in to a CPU game mode, but it turns out "game mode" is different to "game style" with the style being the mode you have created. It's odd, but at least it is in there. So other than re-creating a bit of childhood fun I used to have when I was 10 years old...this game is pretty useless, and I would say it is unfinished.Firstly, there is not a lot of weapon variety in this game compared to other titles I have played in the Worms franchise (The DS version Armageddon comes to mind) which is a shame. And there is nothing particularly as wacky as the other games. Also, half of the sound effects from Worms 3D are completely GONE. And there is a lot less variety in the voices for your worms. The campaign modes are short as well. It has a new campaign (Which is either new to this game or was in Forts: Under Siege) and the campaign from Worms 3D. The Worms 3D only has SEVEN missions, and the new campaign has FOUR. And with each mission taking about 10-15 minutes to beat, that makes the game about 2-3 hours long. There are challenge modes and an online mode, but the online is dead and the challenge missions are pointless with no reason to play them at all unless you REALLY care about pointless score which you can't compare to anyone because there is either no option for leaderboard (I couldn't find one) or there is and no one is using it because no one is playing this game. Only play this if you played Worms 3D and/or Worms Forts: Under Siege on the PS2, just to get a nostalgia rush. But even then you won't be playing the game for very long. I mean, I've put just under 2 hours in and I don't really want to play this anymore.

The Worms 3D only has SEVEN missions, and the new campaign has FOUR. And with each mission taking about 10-15 minutes to beat, that makes the game about 2-3 hours long. There are challenge modes and an online mode, but the online is dead and the challenge missions are pointless with no reason to play them at all unless you REALLY care about pointless score which you can't compare to anyone because there is either no option for leaderboard (I couldn't find one) or there is and no one is using it because no one is playing this game. Only play this if you played Worms 3D and/or Worms Forts: Under Siege on the PS2, just to get a nostalgia rush. But even then you won't be playing the game for very long. I mean, I've put just under 2 hours in and I don't really want to play this anymore.

On far distances crosshair floats and is hard to hit enemy (unless I have Sniper Rifle). Challenges are good, but too easy to beat devs' times (expect Deathmatches).Eventually I would rather back to the Worms 2D interface games (such as Armageddon, Reloaded, Revolution or Clan Wars) than "torture myself" in 3D version of this series. It isn't bad, but I recommend for those who thinks that 3D version of Worms didn't harm them. 												Anyone who's ever played a worms game would know the basic concept. You play as a worm, your job? To kill the opposing worms. Obviously, the main  components in this game is multiplayer, but there's a few other modes for people who can't use multiplayer.... for particular reasons. Let's get right into the multiplayer! The multiplayer works just like every other worms game in the series, turn based. One player goes first, attacks... or not, depends, and then after they have either attacked or ran out of time, the next player goes. Before you start a match though, there's a slot machine, that can be used to randomly select 3 twists to add to your game, your you can choose them yourself! These twists are really interesting, and make every game different from the last. Some of them are; not being able to use anything but ranged weapons, you can only move using the grappling hook,or only being able to use weapons from crates! The online mode is basically the same thing, but no slot machine, and so is single player battles, except you play against a computer.The campaign is by far my favourite part of the game. At the start of each level, you are given an objective, e.g. destroy the building, kill the enemies, climb the tower, all that kind of stuff you would expect. The variety of different levels really keep things fresh, from a dinosaur attack, to the old western, nothing ever seems dull. At the end of each level though, you get coins, which can be used to buy things for your worms in the shop.The shop is where you can buy more things to customize your worms. You see, before you start the actual game, you should make yourself a team. You can name your team members, dress them up, and even choose a speech bank to make them sound like English Bobby,  or even a robot! Not only can you buy things to customize your worm with in the store, but you can also buy new premade levels based on the single player missions to use in multiplayer, or even new game modes! There is also a whole load of items you can only unlock if you own other games on your steam account though. In the end, worms ultimate mayhem is tons of fun with friends, also a whole load of fun in single player,  and with the immense variety of levels and customization options, you will not get bored soon. My final rating is... 8.5/10

												If you've played the old school Worms games, such as the all time classic Worms 2, you'll have a bit of a rough start. 												Anyone who's ever played a worms game would know the basic concept. You play as a worm, your job? To kill the opposing worms. Obviously, the main  components in this game is multiplayer, but there's a few other modes for people who can't use multiplayer.... for particular reasons. Let's get right into the multiplayer! The multiplayer works just like every other worms game in the series, turn based. One player goes first, attacks... or not, depends, and then after they have either attacked or ran out of time, the next player goes. Before you start a match though, there's a slot machine, that can be used to randomly select 3 twists to add to your game, your you can choose them yourself! These twists are really interesting, and make every game different from the last. Some of them are; not being able to use anything but ranged weapons, you can only move using the grappling hook,or only being able to use weapons from crates! The online mode is basically the same thing, but no slot machine, and so is single player battles, except you play against a computer.The campaign is by far my favourite part of the game. At the start of each level, you are given an objective, e.g. destroy the building, kill the enemies, climb the tower, all that kind of stuff you would expect. The variety of different levels really keep things fresh, from a dinosaur attack, to the old western, nothing ever seems dull. At the end of each level though, you get coins, which can be used to buy things for your worms in the shop.The shop is where you can buy more things to customize your worms. You see, before you start the actual game, you should make yourself a team. You can name your team members, dress them up, and even choose a speech bank to make them sound like English Bobby,  or even a robot! Not only can you buy things to customize your worm with in the store, but you can also buy new premade levels based on the single player missions to use in multiplayer, or even new game modes! There is also a whole load of items you can only unlock if you own other games on your steam account though. In the end, worms ultimate mayhem is tons of fun with friends, also a whole load of fun in single player,  and with the immense variety of levels and customization options, you will not get bored soon. My final rating is... 8.5/10

												I have played Worms Ultimate Mayhem 3 hours and counting. I wanted to write this review well after Worms had been released, all of the DLC had been released, and when the modding community had really had a good opportunity to get a foothold in. Worms is an amazing game all in all. To those people who were giving this game 0's and 10's on the very first day it was released, within the first 10 minutes of playing, all I got to say is that those reviews don't help ANYONE. A game like this takes time to grow. GameplayGameplay probably features the biggest changes and improvements of the worms series. Improvements can be found from various aspects of the game, from combat, exploration, crafting and character building. Compared to Worms Reloaded, the combat is much more responsive, faster and dynamic. Enemy variation is amazing in WUM and it was often surprising to see new features and abilities added to already known enemy types. Crafting is one of the biggest and greatest part of WUM. As soon I saw the new crafting system of WUM in E3, I knew it was going to be great and sure wasn’t disappointed. With More Worms DLC you can also build your own robots, and go far as building your own kickass Sentry Bot. With the improved crafting looting and exploration became more important and rewarding. Junk rarity was also in great balance, I often found myself missing needed materials which then motivated me go out to explore the wasteland. With the new crafting system also came the settlement mode, which allowed players to create their own towns and settlements. To me the vanilla settlement mode was dull in many ways. Either way the settlement mode can a lot of fun with mods, allowing you to actually craft something genuine and incredible. The leveling and perk system was also redesigned. While there was nothing wrong with the previous system, the new system was a welcome change. AtmosphereIn general, the atmosphere in WUM is subtler than in previous entries. Fast Food Dino felt much brighter and hopeful than the desolate Gibbon Take or Monster Bash. This is likely due to the more vibrant weathers. To improve immersion, team17 did a nice job of reducing the amount of loading screens. Abandoned towns now could be explored without having to struggle through the 5 second loading screen every now and then.Story and QuestsI personally enjoyed the main plot, mainly because I didn’t expect much of it I got what I expected. Most of the main storyline was very good, it definitely had some memorable moments, difficult choices and the total length of the story wasn’t too bad. As for side content and quests, which were usually good but often hard to find. Radiant quests in WUM have a large role. The highly criticized voiced protagonist and the new dialogue system didn’t bother me, which did undoubtedly pose problems. But to me they were welcome changes, which felt like taking one step back and two steps forward.OverallWhile WUM did sacrifice some of its predecessors RPG elements, it still turned out to be one of the best open-world shooter that I’ve played. Worms did change for better or worse, but as for me, it’s still a Worms game, and a damn good one.
